text: I am currently in Italy (Sicily, Capri, Rome) and have been surprised by how much cash I have needed (versus credit card)… many transportation forms do not accept credit cards, and some vendors don’t… I even had a restaurant tell me no cards. Just an FYI to plan accordingly.

comments.comment_text: Which transportation forms? Vendors of what and where? You always can turn around and pick a next restaurant that does. They can't refuse a card by law.

They definitely prefer cash as there are fees associated with cc some more than others We usually plan cash for cabs ,tips & smaller purchases snacks ect & cc for anything closer to 100 euros. It's not surprising how things can add up but usually min 100-200 a day

It is also a question of kindness and efficiency. Cards carry transaction fees and many service personnel (and businesses) greatly appreciate cash payments and especially tips. And I’m a fan of using credit cards for rewards as long as the debt is paid off ASAP.

I am in Cesenatico/
Rimini and you can pay almost everything with card.
We started with $2,000 euros and paid cash for most things(CCard for hotels that weren't prepaid). We loved the convenience of cash. Went to the ATM as needed during the trip.
CC companies charge them 3% or better for you using your card
Very surprised credit cards are not accepted. Seems in US, cash isn’t accepted anymore. I think because of COVID & germs

Hmmm...I travel to Italy a lot (8× as of May 2023 and will go back again in late August) and I had no issues with paying by card everywhere I go, I only used cash for tips, even in Palermo. But then again, I don't ever use taxi unless I absolutely have to.
The Sicilians don’t like cards, that’s for sure
This for the info. Same in northern Italy ,Rimini area. Now in Spain cards everywhere
By law, they can't refuse cards.
You can’t blame them. I’m currently in France and getting slammed with fees every time that I use my CC.
I use 99% cc in Europe except the small islands in Greece

Restaurants are notorious for claiming they only take cash AFTER you've eaten for tax purposes. A good habit to get into is ask the host/hostess if they take CC's BEFORE you go in. In one instance I asked and they said "Yes, we take CC's". But after our meal we were informed that their CC machine was broken and would need cash. I referenced my conversation with the host before eating because I had no cash. Magically a working machine appeared.
Off topic…. Has it been hard to travel from Sicily to the northern part? Sicily is a must for us but I’m wondering if it would be to much to travel to the north
Chase Sapphire preferred. No fees.

Many of us have said this regarding cash but then the credit card group chimes in that it’s not necessary. There are so many examples of when cash can be needed an the emergencies that can potentially come up. I’m also not starting a verbal argument when a vendor will not accept a credit card. I don’t care what the law is, I’m not doing that on my vacation.

If you want to pay a taxi with your card, call it with the app freenow and pay at the end through the app. It is very difficult having a taxi driver accept a payment with a card. The situation is so bothersome and also illegal that today the Antitrust has opened an inquiry about the topic.
Yup happens a lot.happened in Greece and Portugal as well. For transport locals have special plastic cards so they don't need to pay cash but lots of travelers don't have them ofc
Where did you get the cash from?
In Italy all shops and restaurants MUST have a pos (credit card reader). It is compulsory

text: Looking for advice regarding driving in Italy - Family of four ... checking with Google Maps / directions first !!

In any case don’t drive in Amalfi coast in summer, it’s ok if you go there in autumn. Always ask to your accommodations where to park. Car can be great if you want to have a little more sightseeing.

Take the train! Driving in Italy was almost the end of our marriage. The Autostrada is insane. My husband is a good driver and drives with the flow of traffic, however flow of traffic was 220km/hour… which is about 90 mph. Clearly those drivers knew the road and where they were going… we did not. Paying tolls upon exiting was a whole other level of stress. We only drove from Florence to the Tuscan countryside, but managed to get 2 ZTL violations. Take the train!

We have arrived back home after our whirlwind of a visit, with 7 nights in Italy total.
This is just our experience overall we had a great trip but here are my takeaways. Sorry for the long post!

2 nights Venice - beautiful city but the bridges with large luggage was a nightmare, would definitely book a hotel close to a water bus drop off point 10 euro pp, otherwise you would need a water taxi and preferably one with a lift if you have a fair amount of luggage 😂. Definitely listen when people say pack light! Also one of the days we had was scorching hot and none of the shops have air con 🔥We loved just walking and getting lost and then coming out to a piazza, we also had the most amazing food at De Carletta. Taxis on the mainland were impossible to find, overpriced and there is no Uber etc. We also did not realize they only take cash. But when u are needing to get to a flight you do whatever you need to do to get there. We ended up walking a few km’s with luggage to find one but maybe it was because it was a Sunday. We also found the taxi app couldn’t find our location and to call they don’t speak English 😩

3 nights Sorrento - flew with Ryan air to Naples, we had no problem whatsoever and hand luggage wasn’t looked at. Caught a bus to Sorrento which proved harder than expected to find it was about 800m up the road and bus didn’t have much air con but was an ok way to travel. In our 2 days we spent half a day exploring Sorrento which was enough as there isn’t much there, then went to Pompeii by train which was easy. A guided tour 4.30 tour was perfect as it wasn’t hot🥵 Our second day we did a boat tour to Capri, just our opinion but at this time of the season especially it was very overrated. Crowed, hot and waiting in long lines for the cable car to go to overpriced restaurants and shops. We ended up getting the public bus which proved much quicker. It also didn’t help that we booked late online and I feel our tour was very overpriced, for a trip with 12 people to the island and a short trip around it with a swimming stop, (blue grotto was closed) 160 euro pp. Next time I would book from the mainland directly. Food was amazing in Sorrento especially the orange tree and Qui bistro 🥰

1 night Rome - we caught the ferry to Naples which was great but a 30euro taxi for 7mins drive 😬again no Uber and had to get hotel to call and book, then another 20euro from airport to train. Next time would just take the train from Sorrento. We were supposed to catch the fast train but were rushing and caught the slow train instead so got in one hr late 😩 note to self triple check train numbers! Once in Rome at 11am we did the hop on hop off bus which was great and stopped near all the major attractions. We even got a last minute guided tour of the colosseum at the gate 40 euro pp. We ticked off all of the major places all by 4pm 👌

1 night Florence - We arrived by train to Florence and went straight to our highlight tour of the trip. Booked through viator Fun in Tuscany a horse ride through the vineyards, with a stop at San Grimiono and 3 course lunch with wine tasting at a winery. It was all amazing would highly recommend! Approx 200euro pp 8hrs. They also stored our luggage in the bus and waited when our train was 10 minutes late. That night we went up to Michelangelo’s piazza to watch the sunset, it was very busy so get there early but was amazing 🤩. The final day we walked Florence and seen most of the major landmarks whilst shopping for the best priced leather we found in the markets.

All in all we had an amazing time even though it was short and we learnt a lot. I hope this was helpful to some ❤️

This fall will be our 5th trip to Italy in 2 years. Here's what I would do for my first trip to Italy (and what I in fact did do for my first trip there) though I imagine that I'm probably in the minority:

First of all, don't go in the summer or even the late spring or early fall. I would completely black out my vacation calendar from April 21th - September 21th. That still leaves you with 7 months! Unless you just feel that you *must* lay on the beach and get in the water. In which case I would try to avoid July and *for sure* avoid August.

Secondly, and most importantly, don't go to any of the *major* tourist destinations! Venice, Rome, Cinque Terra, Florence, Pisa, Tuscan countryside, Amalfi Coast, and Lake Como. Or, go to just one and for just 1-2 days. The rest of the time should be spent at any number of places that are awesome, which is the vast majority of Italy! Almost everywhere in the country is a tourist destination, and that includes 100s of places that you've likely never heard of! Trust me on this, you will see amazing beauty and culture in other places which will fulfill you and make you feel as if you have had a full vacation while not having to navigate the hordes and compete for all the same services as so many others are also competing for. Not to mention that you will avoid so many of the places that just exist to get those tourism dollars and therefore aren't such an authentic aspect of Italy.

If you must go in the summer but you avoid the most touristy of tourist areas, you'll find that while others are on pages like this complaining about how busy it is, that you are having a grand time in places with a more manageable tourist population.

There are loads of places that are jaw-droppingly amazing, similar to the places that are jam-packed that you can go to. Really. You want Lake Como? Go to Lake Iseo (or Lake Garda or Lake Maggiore for busy but not as busy as Lake Como). You want Tuscany? Go to Umbria. You want Rome, go to Bologna. You won't be disappointed. And there's lots of other fantastic places to visit. 100s of places that if any of them were in the U.S. they would be the biggest tourist destinations in the country. But also just as old and special and beautiful as most of what you’ll see in those more famous places.

Goodness! So many answers here, and no two are alike. ￼ I have visited the Vatican museums four times. Here are my suggestions which I hope will be helpful.
1) Skip the advice of people that say “don’t go in August “! Yes, it is going to be hot and it’s going to be crowded but I assume your trip is already booked and you will still love it!
2) ￼ My best bet has always been booking directly with the Vatican Museums website. Be sure to scroll down and click on “more bookable options’. Anything you book on their site is technically a “skip the line“ because you have a timed entry. You will go to the main entrance, show your voucher, then walk into the main lobby area, through security, and pick up your tickets. You can select from a guided tour or a self guided tour. It sounds like you might lean toward the self-guided tour. In that case, you go through the museums at your own pace and arrive at the Sistine chapel on the far end. When you come out of the chapel, you can continue through the museums back to the entrance. You cannot go directly into St. Peter’s basilica, unless you are on a specific outside tour that includes direct entry. That option is not available on the Vatican Museums site.
3) the only way to avoid some of the heat and crowds in August, would be to book one of the early morning or breakfast tours. These are always highly recommended. Otherwise, any other time of day, the crowds can be overwhelming. Staying with a guide, does give you the advantage of being navigated through some of the most congested areas.
4) St Peter’s is free to enter from St Peter￼’s Square. Do be aware that the line to enter through security will be daunting. Depending on the time of day and the weather, you might expect to be in line for 2 to 3 hours If you only have a couple of days in Rome, you decide if that is a priority. Also, if you are in Rome, on a Wednesday, the Basilica will be closed in the mornings as pope Francis will be having his public audience in the Square. I can tell you that the basilica IS incredible but there are also many stunning cathedrals and basilicas throughout the city that you can enter at any time without a wait.
4) if everything is sold out on the Vatican Museums site, there are several good, locally run tour options that might have availability. I highly recommend checking out Katie’s Untold Italy website for recommendations
, links, and even a discount code or two. I recently booked a private tour for a couple that will be traveling with me in October to see the Vatican and basilica on their 50th anniversary through Liv Tours (via Katie’s link) and the communication has been wonderful.
5) finally, take all advice with a grain of salt! You do you! Some will say that the Sistine chapel was the highlight of their trip, while others say it is underwhelming. That’s OK!
￼ Wishing you a magical, memorable, and beautiful trip to Italy. You will keep it in your heart forever. ❤️ ￼
